content: The Act is titled the "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" aims to ensure safe water supply and wastewater systems for residents of the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico. It authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to plan, design, and construct these systems in collaboration with the Jicarilla Apache Nation. The Bureau of Reclamation, in consultation with the Jicarilla Apache Nation, plans to construct water supply, delivery, and wastewater systems on the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico. This includes service connections to facilities in Dulce and the surrounding area, as well as individuals. At the request of the Nation, the Secretary will enter into a self-determination agreement. The Bureau of Reclamation plans to construct water supply, delivery, and wastewater systems on the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico, including service connections to facilities in Dulce and the surrounding area. At the request of the Nation, the Secretary will enter into a self-determination agreement for the construction. The Jicarilla Apache Nation will plan, design, and construct water supply, delivery, and wastewater systems with oversight from the Bureau of Reclamation under a self-determination agreement. The Jicarilla Apache Nation will assume ownership and responsibility for wastewater collection systems with oversight from the Bureau of Reclamation. The Jicarilla Apache Nation will take over wastewater collection systems under Bureau of Reclamation oversight. SEC. 3 defines key terms. The Act defines key terms including "Act" as the Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act, "BIA" as the Bureau of Indian Affairs, "irrigation" as the commercial application of water for agriculture, and "Reclamation" as the Bureau of Reclamation. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of terms related to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act, including "Reclamation" as the Bureau of Reclamation and "Report" as a specific report related to water and wastewater improvements. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act, including "Report" as a specific report on water and wastewater improvements, "Reservation" as the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico, and "Rural Water Supply Project" as a project for municipal, domestic, and rural water supply. The term "Reservation" refers to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico, including lands held in trust by the United States for the Tribe. A "Rural Water Supply Project" is a facility serving towns, communities, tribal reservations, and farmsteads with clean water access. A "Supply Project" is a water supply and wastewater facility serving towns, communities, cities, tribal reservations, and farmsteads with clean water access, including livestock use. The terms "State," "Secretary," and "Tribe" refer to the State of New Mexico, the Secretary of the Interior (Bureau of Reclamation), and the Jicarilla Apache Nation, respectively. SEC. 4. JICARILLA APACHE RESERVATION RURAL WATER SYSTEM. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will construct the Rural Water Supply Project to improve water supply, delivery, and wastewater facilities in Dulce, New Mexico, and surrounding communities. The project includes facilities for water supply, delivery, and wastewater services for Dulce, Mundo Ranch Development, and surrounding areas on the Reservation. The Rural Water Supply Project will include facilities for water supply, delivery, and wastewater services in Dulce, Mundo Ranch Development, and surrounding areas on the Reservation, including pumping and treatment facilities, distribution, collection, and treatment facilities. The Rural Water Supply Project on the Reservation includes pumping and treatment facilities, distribution, collection, and treatment facilities, appurtenant buildings, access roads, necessary property rights, and other electrical power transmission facilities. The Rural Water Supply Project on the Reservation includes existing water and wastewater systems, appurtenant buildings, access roads, necessary property rights, and other facilities deemed necessary by the Secretary to meet water supply needs. The Rural Water Supply Project on the Reservation includes facilities deemed necessary by the Secretary to meet water supply needs, such as water storage tanks, water lines, maintenance equipment, and other facilities for the Tribe. The tribal share of the project's cost includes designing and initiating construction of a wastewater treatment plant, replacing the diversion structure on the Navajo River, and constructing raw materials. The tribal share of the cost for the Rural Water Supply Project on the Reservation includes designing and initiating construction of a wastewater treatment plant, replacing the diversion structure on the Navajo River, and constructing raw water settling ponds, a water treatment plant, water storage plants, a water transmission pipeline, and distribution pipelines. The Federal share of the cost is also outlined. The Federal share of the cost for the Rural Water Supply Project includes constructing various water infrastructure components, such as a water treatment plant, storage plants, and pipelines. The Federal share also covers operation and maintenance costs. Upon completion of the Rural Water Supply Project, the Tribe will assume responsibility for operation, maintenance, and replacement as per the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Tribe will assume responsibility for operation, maintenance, and replacement of the Rural Water Supply Project in accordance with the Indian Self-Determination Act after it is deemed substantially complete by the Secretary. The Secretary has the authority to enter agreements and regulations to implement the Act and the Indian Self-Determination Act. Project requirements must be met by the Tribe for the Rural Water Supply Project. The Secretary must prepare a project plan for the Rural Water Supply Project within 60 days of funds availability. The Tribe must develop an operation, maintenance, and replacement plan to establish rates and fees for customers. The Tribe must develop an operation, maintenance, and replacement plan for the Rural Water Supply Project. The Secretary will select a project construction manager to assist in planning, design, and construction. A memorandum of agreement will be entered into between the Secretary, Reclamation, BIA, and the Tribe. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will select a construction manager for the Rural Water Supply Project. A memorandum of agreement will be made with the Tribe to address operations and maintenance during and after construction. The Secretary will oversee the project with the Tribe and its constructing entity. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will select a construction manager for the Rural Water Supply Project. A memorandum of agreement with the Tribe commits Reclamation and BIA to a transition plan for operations and maintenance during and after construction. The Secretary will provide oversight and technical assistance to the Tribe for planning, development, and construction of the project. The Secretary will provide technical assistance to the Tribe for planning, developing, and constructing the Rural Water Supply Project within the Reservation boundaries. The project will adhere to the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Rural Water Supply Project within the Reservation boundaries will receive technical assistance from the Secretary and must adhere to the Indian Self-Determination Act. The service area of the project is limited to the Reservation boundaries, and the project's planning, design, construction, operation, and maintenance will be reported annually to Congress by the Secretary in consultation with the Tribe. The Rural Water Supply Project within the Reservation boundaries will be held in trust for the Tribe by the United States and must adhere to the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Secretary will report annually to Congress on the project's planning, design, and construction in consultation with the Tribe. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorized appropriation of $45,000,000 for Rural Water Supply Project planning, design, and construction. Funds cannot be used until appraisal investigation and feasibility study are completed by the Secretary and the Tribe. The Rural Water Supply Project requires completion of an appraisal investigation, feasibility study, and a plan as per the conditions outlined in the Report dated September 2001. The Secretary must also ensure compliance with the National Environmental Policy Act before funds can be allocated for construction. SEC. 8. PROHIBITION ON USE OF FUNDS FOR IRRIGATION PURPOSES. None of the funds for the Rural Water Supply Project can be used for irrigation facilities. SEC. 9. WATER RIGHTS. The Jicarilla Apache Tribe Water Rights Settlement Act (Public Law 102-441) grants the Tribe water rights adjudicated under New Mexico State law. These rights provide sufficient water for the municipal water system and are recognized depletions within the San Juan River basin. No new depletions are associated with the Rural Water Supply Project. Reclamation, in consultation with the Fish and Wildlife Service, has confirmed this. The Rural Water Supply Project has sufficient water rights to supply the municipal water system, with no new depletions associated. Reclamation has confirmed no significant impact on endangered species, and no other Tribe water rights will be affected.
